channel.title: myndworkz
channel.description: Slicing and dicing the world at its joints

item.title: Let me tell you a story
item.dc:creator: brynrwilliams
item.content:encoded:
Hi, my name is Bryn Williams and my story is a twisty one. After leaving school at 17 I spend years travelling. I take various jobs in this time, mostly in pubs, bars, hotels and clubs, but also petrol stations, building sites, farms and vineyards.  

The next chapter is university, where I earn three degrees in philosophy: BA, M.Phil and PhD. 

There's a short interval where I start Pub Philosophy in London's Soho, and take it on tour to New Zealand and Australia.  It is still running weekly in London as the Philosophy Cabin.

The next chapter of my career began when I turned a temporary role at Guy’s & St Thomas’ NHS Foundation Trust into a long-term position, where I developed a variety of data applications to improve healthcare services and outcomes, reduce duplication and workloads, and support clinical research projects. Over the years, I also played a key role in supporting educational programs and training initiatives aimed at improving patient safety and clinical quality.

I closed that chapter working as part of the Apollo team that successfully delivered the biggest and most ambitious rollout of the Epic integrated electronic health record to two of the largest Trusts in the UK simultaneously.

The next chapter starts here. After taking early retirement, I got married and relocated to Geneva, where I have embarked on a new journey as an English language teacher. With a CELTA qualification, I am excited to apply my background in education and analysis to help learners achieve their language goals.

Best regards, Bryn.

item.title: Training and support for all staff to use Social Media tools
item.dc:creator: brynrwilliams
item.content:encoded: To some, this may seem a strange thing to promote in the workplace. Traditionally, tools like Twitter have been looked on with disdain - as a distraction from work and of no value either to the Trust or the patients we serve. Outside of healthcare, this view has been successfully challenged for years as being out of date and counter-productive. All sorts of industries have adopted a positive approach to Social Media, encouraging and enabling their employees to connect widely and deeply. The benefit to the company is a far better informed workforce and, specifically, staff that are better informed in their own areas of work. The benefit to the staff is that they are better at what they do, which brings greater job security and job satisfaction This all flows from better engagement with  colleagues both within the workplace and across their professions. The good news is that the NHS is catching up. NHS England recommends and practices active Social Media engagement. The Department of Health, as a government body, is bound by rules that specify their employees should not be hampered by IT policies from making use of any Social Media tools available to them to connect to their clients - the public. Guy's and St Thomas' is also getting to grips with Social Media. The twitter handle @GSTTnhs is well publicised and at the moment of writing has 2,085 followers, picking up 44 this month (5 today). There is also a new Social Media policy (available from GTi) which sets out the rules for individuals or departments wishing to have their own public identity on the web. Healthcare is getting connected. I believe that, equally, those that work in  healthcare  need to get connected. If elected I will argue that we need to be actively promoting, encouraging and supporting greater use of Social Media by every employee in the Trust from the CEO down. I've placed a link here to Southern Health NHS Foundation Trust who  are already moving in this direction.  Southern Health Social Media Guidance and another link to their Social Media FAQs (very useful resource). I encourage you to follow the links to see a successful example of a positive trust-wide Social Media promotion strategy. Don't forget - election papers will start appearing on Wednesday  15 May and have to be returned by Friday June 7. Vote for who you prefer, but PLEASE VOTE! Here’s yet another reminder, you can communicate with me by leaving a comment on this blog, following me on twitter @BrynRWilliams, using the  #GSTTCoGNCS13 hashtag or  connecting with me on LinkedIn uk.linkedin.com/in/brynrwilliams

item.title: rosie - 2013-05-31 15:46:04
item.content:encoded: I have found issues with training programes not being provided for lower band staff. I contacted the training department to see if i could do a continuation of my ILM and was told that due to me being a band 3 i was not eligable for this. (despite me having a degree in BSC hons leisure management and marketing of which i gained a 2:1) I thought this was unfair and discriminating against the lower bands. It would be good to have a fairer recruiting system where they notify you if you have been unsuccessful on an application. <!--more--> AUTHOR: rosie AUTHOR EMAIL: rosemarie.parsons@gstt.nhs.uk AUTHOR URL: SUBJECT: #GSTTCoGNCS13 IP: 161.17.0.1 Array ( [Name] => rosie [Email] => rosemarie.parsons@gstt.nhs.uk [Comment] => I have found issues with training programes not being provided for lower band staff. I contacted the training department to see if i could do a continuation of my ILM and was told that due to me being a band 3 i was not eligable for this. (despite me having a degree in BSC hons leisure management and marketing of which i gained a 2:1) I thought this was unfair and discriminating against the lower bands. It would be good to have a fairer recruiting system where they notify you if you have been unsuccessful on an application. )

item.title: Amanda Hesman - 2013-06-04 23:07:43
item.content:encoded:
Hi Bryn,
I work as a nurse lecturer at LSBU and stumbled across your twitter account whilst doing some prep for a forthcoming module (Politics of Health).I have a few (too many) hats here 1) I am a Link Lecturer for students nurses at GSTT, including Mark Ward! So am really interested in the 'toxic culture' and now I have to think about how I approach this. 2) As uni lecturers we don't have access to nhs net so free wi fi wld be really helpful for student visits and student support. Perhaps the Student Union at LSBU could help you with you campaign ... 3) I have recently been treated for cancer at GSTT and have experienced mostly excellent care which has really reinvigorated my belief in the NHS and want to be supportive of GSTT, hence my concern about Mark Ward.
Good luck with your campaign , Amanda <!--more--> AUTHOR: Amanda Hesman AUTHOR EMAIL: hesmanaj@lsbu.ac.uk AUTHOR URL: SUBJECT: #GSTTCoGNCS13 IP: 81.129.246.237 Array ( [Name] => Amanda Hesman [Email] => hesmanaj@lsbu.ac.uk [Comment] => Hi Bryn,
I work as a nurse lecturer at LSBU and stumbled across your twitter account whilst doing some prep for a forthcoming module (Politics of Health).I have a few (too many) hats here 1) I am a Link Lecturer for students nurses at GSTT, including Mark Ward! So am really interested in the 'toxic culture' and now I have to think about how I approach this. 2) As uni lecturers we don't have access to nhs net so free wi fi wld be really helpful for student visits and student support. Perhaps the Student Union at LSBU could help you with you campaign ... 3) I have recently been treated for cancer at GSTT and have experienced mostly excellent care which has really reinvigorated my belief in the NHS and want to be supportive of GSTT, hence my concern about Mark Ward.
Good luck with your campaign , Amanda )

item.title: Welcome to myndworkz
item.dc:creator: brynrwilliams
item.content:encoded:
Hello. I am a CELTA-certified English language teacher with a background in healthcare data analysis and education. I recently transitioned from a 20-year career as a Principal Business Analyst in the NHS, where I developed expertise in educational program design, process improvement, and data-driven insights. My passion for helping others achieve their goals has led me to a new career in teaching English to adults, where I apply my skills in lesson planning, communication, and student-centered learning.

In addition to my CELTA qualification, I hold a PhD in Philosophy, which has equipped me with strong analytical skills, including logic, statistics, and critical thinking. My previous experience includes designing and delivering educational programs that improved clinical outcomes and staff training, and I now bring that same commitment to my work as an English language teacher.

As a CELTA-qualified teacher, I offer:

  • Tailored English lessons for adults, focusing on communicative language teaching and helping learners build confidence in their speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills.
  • Specialized support for professionals seeking to improve their English for business, academic, or everyday use.
  • Structured lesson plans that prioritize student needs, whether they’re learning English for career advancement, travel, or personal growth.
  • A student-centered approach, ensuring each learner’s individual goals are met through engaging, practical lessons.

I’m excited to offer my services to individuals and organizations looking for personalized, effective English language teaching. My approach is built on years of experience in education and data-driven project management, ensuring my students receive high-quality instruction that is clear, focused, and results-oriented.

Whether you're looking to improve your English for professional reasons or personal development, I am here to guide you. I bring dedication, expertise, and a passion for teaching to every session, ensuring you can confidently achieve your English language goals.

If you're looking for a professional, experienced English teacher committed to your success, please get in touch to discuss how I can help you on your language learning journey.

CELTA CVDownload

item.title: Philosophy Workshops
item.dc:creator: brynrwilliams
item.content:encoded:
Incorporating philosophical discussions into the workplace can lead to a more thoughtful, inclusive, and innovative corporate culture, ultimately benefiting the CEO, employees, and the business as a whole.

  1. Enhanced Critical Thinking: Philosophical discussions encourage participants to think critically and analytically, fostering a culture of problem-solving within the organization.
  2. Diverse Perspectives: Engaging with different viewpoints from colleagues and strangers can lead to innovative solutions by considering a wider range of ideas and experiences.
  3. Improved Decision-Making: Exploring ethical and moral dilemmas through philosophical discourse can help refine decision-making processes and promote ethical business practices.
  4. Strengthened Relationships: Philosophical conversations promote camaraderie and mutual understanding among employees, leading to stronger team cohesion and improved workplace relationships.
  5. Conflict Resolution Skills: Practicing civil discourse on philosophical topics equips individuals with valuable conflict resolution skills, which can reduce workplace conflicts.
  6. Enhanced Communication: Employees who engage in philosophical discussions tend to become better communicators, aiding in clearer and more effective communication within the organization.
  7. Fostering Inclusivity: Encouraging open dialogue on philosophical issues can promote inclusivity and diversity, ensuring that all voices are heard and respected.
  8. Personal Growth: Philosophical discussions can stimulate personal growth, as participants reflect on their beliefs and values, potentially leading to increased self-awareness and emotional intelligence.
  9. Innovation and Creativity: Exploring abstract concepts can spark creativity and innovation, potentially leading to the development of new ideas and solutions in the business.
  10. Attracting Talent: A corporate culture that values philosophical discussions can be attractive to top talent who seek intellectual stimulation and a stimulating work environment.
  11. Public Image: Demonstrating a commitment to thoughtful discourse can enhance the public image of the company, showing it as a socially responsible and forward-thinking organization.
  12. Employee Satisfaction: Employees who feel their voices are heard and respected in philosophical discussions are more likely to be satisfied with their workplace, contributing to higher retention rates.
  13. Adaptability: Engaging in philosophical debates encourages adaptability, helping the organization remain agile and responsive in a rapidly changing business landscape.
  14. Long-Term Vision: Philosophical discussions can encourage long-term thinking and strategic planning, which is crucial for sustained business success.
  15. Corporate Social Responsibility: Addressing philosophical issues can align the company with ethical and social responsibility goals, which can be appealing to customers and investors.
